description: gilt bronze mounted with three emerald green jade plaques. The ju-i was an object much used by the Chinese for presentation purposes, in addition to its regular use as a ceremonial scepter. Former Classification: Jade
text: Symbolic of good wishes, the ju-i (literally "as you wish") is a sceptre-like object first encountered in Buddhist art. By virtue of its auspicious name, it became a favorite motif in the decorative arts of the Ch'ing period (1644-1912). Placed on a writing desk or held in the hand, ju-i sceptres were made from a variety of materials including jade, carved lacquer, wood, cloisonn√© and porcelain. This spectacular gold and jade sceptre, decorated with the eight precious symbols of Buddhism, is from the imperial collection.
title: Ju-i Scepter
